description: {"blocks":[{"key":"dtvkn","text":"KASP is a genotyping assay which you can use to differentiate wild types vs heterozygous vs homozygous larvae/finclips. It is well suited to genotype a SNP or a small CRISPR-generated indel. Once you confirmed it is working well, the assay is pretty fast to run so you may want to use KASP if you will routinely genotype tens of samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"249br","text":"Eirinn Mackay, a Fish Floor alumnus (Wilson lab), created an online tool to create the KASP primer. This circumvents using the company's service, which charges ~ 60£ for a simple mix of three PCR primers.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a6dti","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"425sp","text":"Go to","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a410s","text":"https://kasp.eirinn.org/","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":24}],"data":{}},{"key":"abtqi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63nlt","text":"We are assuming here that you already sequenced your allele (usually with Illumina MiSeq or Sanger) to know what the mutation is.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"BE85EF4E80B911EDA92F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://kasp.eirinn.org"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bg2sj","text":"PCR programme (from official KASP's protocol):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":20,"length":24}],"data":{}},{"key":"4o4e8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d1ip9","text":"1. 94˚C – 15 min","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d5mil","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fbl8","text":"2. 94˚C – 20 sec","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5j78j","text":"3. 61–55˚C – 60 sec","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a7at6","text":"\u003e back to 2. for 10 more cycles (11 total).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"67fdp","text":"Decreasing 0.6˚C per cycle, so: 61, 60.4, 59.8, 59.2, 58.6, 58, 57.4, 56.8, 56.2, 55.6, 55.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cuunn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bsfoq","text":"4. 94˚C – 20 sec","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"enrrf","text":"5. 55˚C – 60 sec","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bg8ul","text":"\u003e back to 4. for 26 more cycles (27 total).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"C2CD49E3E49247328DFF1D55F6D31511","url":"https://biosearch-cdn.azureedge.net/assetsv6/KASP-thermal-cycling-conditions-all-protocols.pdf"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c3prf","text":"When you receive the lyophilised primers, you can prepare 100 µM stocks in nuclease-free H2O. For example, if one primer is 16.4 nmoles, you want to add 164 µL nuclease-free H2O to make a 100 µM stock. Vortex and spin-down a couple of times to make sure that the pellet was dissolved completely.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6jlp4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e930s","text":"Next, prepare a KASP primer mix (all three primers together) such as that***:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"415jb","text":"COM primer =   ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":13,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fbbc3","text":"WT primer =   ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":12,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b8v43","text":"MUT primer =  ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":13,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2egeg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75m9g","text":"For example, to make 200 µL of KASP primer mix from the 100 µM stocks:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2rde6","text":"  COM primer (100 µM)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4qsgk","text":"  WT primer (100 µM)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":4,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7idfq","text":"  MUT primer (100 µM)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":5,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7ccci","text":"  nuclease-free H2O","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":6,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8vs34","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ds7nu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":7,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2f1l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"concentration":"29","error_concentration":false,"guid":"7CFD9A4098B911EDA8EDD15F526DA3F9","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":29}},"1":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"concentration":"14.5","error_concentration":false,"guid":"99B8A4E098B911EDA8EDD15F526DA3F9","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":29}},"2":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"concentration":"14.5","error_concentration":false,"guid":"A5F1D22798B911EDB49F0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":29}},"3":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"58","error":false,"guid":"09E00A1098BA11EDA8EDD15F526DA3F9","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"4":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"29","error":false,"guid":"1193A0A098BA11EDA8EDD15F526DA3F9","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"5":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"29","error":false,"guid":"237ACB8F98BA11EDB49F0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"6":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"84","error":false,"guid":"399F65C098BA11EDA8EDD15F526DA3F9","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"7":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"83kmc","text":"*** My logic for these concentrations was: for a standard PCR, I usually put a total of 0.6 µL (2 × 0.3 µL) of 20 µM primer in a reaction volume of 20 µL, i.e. final primer concentration = 0.8 µM. Here, we use 0.056 µL of primer mix in a final volume of 4.056 µL (see below). Therefore, to reach the same final primer concentration, we want a primer stock of 58 µM. In the case of a heterozygous sample, the COM primer works on 100% of the templates while the WT and MUT primers only amplify 50% of the templates each, so the COM primer's concentration should be double the WT and MUT primer's concentrations, i.e. the 58 µM total primer concentration should be splitted as: 29 µM COM / 14.5 µM WT / 14.5 MUT.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7t4ng","text":"Think about the lay-out of your plate.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ae5m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"508a6","text":"Make sure to include minimum 3 non-template control (NTC) wells. Include more if you have enough free wells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dbclv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6mp2h","text":"When first testing the KASP assay, also include a few samples which you know are wild-type at this locus. You can also include some other samples of known genotypes, for example the samples you sequenced to confirm that you are obtaining the same results with KASP and sequencing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ci4ff","text":"You can find some excellent videos on YouTube which explains the concept.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bui43","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1rvgm","text":"KASP is based on a PCR with three primers:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ctm4h","text":"one primer specific to the wild-type allele (WT primer)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"chrt6","text":"one primer specific to the mutant allele (MUT primer)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7iu34","text":"one primer common to both alleles (COM primer)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e4sv0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"edcn6","text":"The WT and MUT primers are both Forward and the COM primer is Reverse, or vice-versa.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79s2c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"di5m4","text":"The WT and MUT primers 5′ carry tags on which a fluorophore is bound during PCR. This allows to differentiate the three genotypes when reading the plate after PCR:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6muq5","text":"Wild-type: high signal in channel 1 only","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"45ju1","text":"Homozygous: high signal in channel 2 only","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c0q83","text":"Heterozygous: high signal in both channels","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b6e1l","text":"Need help obtaining the sequence of the wild-type/mutant alleles?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":65},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":65}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1h3l4","text":"Say you only know through sequencing a small window around the mutation, for example:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7qus1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"er2pp","text":"Wild-type:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"n4e3","text":"GAGTATGAAGCCCTCCACGAAGATGAGTTG","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8v4t9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dsbds","text":"Mutant (2-bp deletion):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9o8iv","text":"GAGTATGAAGCCCTC--CGAAGATGAGTTG","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"22pns","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"43cs3","text":"We can find the genomic position of the mutation with BLAST.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2v4p3","text":"https://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":40}],"data":{}},{"key":"esoes","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e4566","text":"Under BLAST Genomes, type Danio rerio \u003e Search.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":26,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8r9k7","text":"Enter the wild-type sequence from above \u003e BLAST.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9u8cb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8rcpj","text":"The top result should be the correct match. Check that Query cover and Percentage Identity (Per. Ident) are both 100%. Click on the result.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aepth","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4cuki","text":"You will obtain the start and stop positions of the small sequence, in our case: chr20:35900655–35900684.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"650ef","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9f401","text":"The mutation is the deletion of CA in the middle. Count from the start and you should find that the deletion is chr20:35900670–71. Record it somewhere for the future.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":32,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8vj9s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dioh","text":"Now go to the UCSC Genome Browser for Danio rerio reference genome danRer11:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":38,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1o42r","text":"https://genome-euro.ucsc.edu/cgi-bin/hgTracks?db=danRer11","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":57}],"data":{}},{"key":"6kd9h","text":"Search for the position of the mutation: chr20:35900670.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7sebf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"vl01","text":"Check that you are at the right place, for example that you see your gene of interest and that this nucleotide/the surrounding ones are those you expect from sequencing (you can zoom out for this).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2vhl4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d3faj","text":"View \u003e DNA.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ogqm","text":"In Position, you should have your position of interest, in our case: chr20:35,900,670-35,900,670.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d4j65","text":"Add 100 extra bases upstream (5') and 100 extra downstream (3').","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":38,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cehjg","text":"Click extended case/color options \u003e change Letters per line to a big number e.g. 999.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1f8il","text":"Submit.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e7f72","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3k0b7","text":"You now have a 200-bp genomic window centered on the position of your mutation (i.e. ~ 100 bp on either side). This is your wild-type sequence, in our case:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":124,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4vq5h","text":"AAAAATAGGTGGATGGAAATGTAGCTACAGATAACAGGTACTGAGATGTGTTGTTGTCTCTGCAGTTGAGGTGGTGGTGGAGTATGAGTATGAAGCCCTCCACGAAGATGAGTTGACCCTCAGGCTTGGAGACATCATCAAAAACGTACGACGCATCGAAGAGGAGGGATGGATGGAAGGAGACCTCAACGGCAAACGAGG","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":201}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"614qv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5bgr9","text":"To create the mutant sequence, simply replace the deleted CA by --. You should obtain:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":14,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"413dc","text":"AAAAATAGGTGGATGGAAATGTAGCTACAGATAACAGGTACTGAGATGTGTTGTTGTCTCTGCAGTTGAGGTGGTGGTGGAGTATGAGTATGAAGCCCTC--CGAAGATGAGTTGACCCTCAGGCTTGGAGACATCATCAAAAACGTACGACGCATCGAAGAGGAGGGATGGATGGAAGGAGACCTCAACGGCAAACGAGG","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":201},{"style":"bold","offset":100,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"D4B64612813411ED867A0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"94807DE1813511ED867A0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://genome-euro.ucsc.edu/cgi-bin/hgTracks?db=danRer11"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bc0po","text":"Enter your wild-type and mutant sequences in https://kasp.eirinn.org/.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":45,"length":24}],"data":{}},{"key":"dr11a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5dlhg","text":"It creates two set of three primers:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3j0tk","text":"One Forward set, where the WT and MUT primers are Forward and the COM primer is Reverse.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"56al3","text":"One Reverse set, where the WT and MUT primers are Reverse and the COM primer is Forward.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e027h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8quka","text":"Order the three primers of the Forward set, as you would for any PCR primers.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dghva","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11an5","text":"The three primers of the Reverse set serve as \"second try\" if the Forward set does not work. You can buy them now too (short DNA oligos are cheap) or wait to try the Forward set first.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"2FA4015E813711ED867A0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://kasp.eirinn.org"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"a0ut9","text":"Use a white, low-profile PCR plate.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8d7vn","text":"Also get a normal seal.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

MasterMix.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ac7kb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"us6a","text":"Per well:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"31oah","text":"  2× KASP mix","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"q61i","text":"   primer mix","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cfha3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6p3hg","text":"Prepare 15–20% extra.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8h5s8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"23f0e","text":"For example, for 96 wells, prepare for 115 wells:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e4mul","text":"   2× KASP mix","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":1,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cnt4m","text":"  primer mix","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"anlnd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d0tp5","text":"Leave   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":4,"offset":6,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"2","error":false,"guid":"12EEEB00813911EDB4DDE5488C862A7F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"0.056","error":false,"guid":"3BC13470813911EDB4DDE5488C862A7F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"230","error":false,"guid":"9EF3CC10813911EDB4DDE5488C862A7F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"3":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"6.44","error":false,"guid":"ADF0C5B0813911EDB4DDE5488C862A7F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"4":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"D91EB260813911EDB4DDE5488C862A7F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"","unit":165}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8qql6","text":"Pipet   of genomic DNA in each well.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":6,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4ied6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3mu4a","text":"Try to place the drop on the wall on one side (always the same) of each well.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4894k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"chv1p","text":"You can use a 8-tip multichannel pipet, in which case you fill the plate column by column; or a 12-tip multichannel pipet, in which case you fill the plate row by row. I prefer the 8-tip one.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"536av","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"esioe","text":"In the NTC wells, you should ideally pipet   of the buffer in which your genomic DNA is, typically a 50:50 mix of 1× BASE and 1× NEUTRALISATION solutions from HotSHOT. Alternatively,   of nuclease-free H2O should work fine as well.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":43,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":183,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"2","error":false,"guid":"E0650830813911EDB4DDE5488C862A7F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"2","error":false,"guid":"CEC29BA0813A11EDB4DDE5488C862A7F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"2","error":false,"guid":"B8513750813A11EDB4DDE5488C862A7F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6t9g0","text":"Pipet   of MasterMix in each well.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":6,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dleva","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cpg4q","text":"Place the drop on the wall on the side opposite the genomic DNA. If you are careful about not touching the genomic DNA, you do not need to replace tip at every well. I usually change tip only once per column or row or when pipetting into the NTC wells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"2","error":false,"guid":"147F80A0813A11EDB4DDE5488C862A7F","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"617p9","text":"Are you on FishFloor @UCL? The plate readers are in the Central Lab with Bill. You should book your visit on the Google Calendar. I usually use the CFX1 machine, so qpcrcfx1@gmail.com.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":165,"length":18}],"data":{}},{"key":"ao8lh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9bvd6","text":"Open software.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e6n38","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6lque","text":"Plate \u003e Edit selected","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"33u07","text":"    \u003e right click on one NTC (no template control) well, Copy Well","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"atsdr","text":"    \u003e select your negative control wells, Paste Wells","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4g6mn","text":"    \u003e any empty well, select and Clear Wells (right column)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ctkdm","text":"    \u003e leave positive controls as Unknown","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1utrj","text":"(so should be all Unknown or NTC)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"clfuh","text":"\u003e Save plate","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7dq5n","text":"\u003e Next","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"47ldb","text":"\u003e make sure CFX1 is ticked","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6a9l0","text":"\u003e click on Open lid","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"57ppm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7gfrc","text":"Place your plate","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"28i4c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dodih","text":"\u003e click on Close lid","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ihli","text":"\u003e Start Run","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fqpod","text":"\u003e save results in your folder","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"DC315C34813B11EDA1DF0A58A9FEAC02","url":"mailto:qpcrcfx1@gmail.com"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7sta6","text":"Results should pop up","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4bus0","text":"\u003e Allele discrimination","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9vr8c","text":"\u003e tick View call map","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1it9k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fva65","text":"The scatterplot is X = first colour/channel, Y = second colour/channel.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f5di7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"771fr","text":"In an ideal world:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"arcp9","text":"all the NTC wells are labelled black and are in the bottom left corner, i.e. low fluorescence in both channels","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"peq4","text":"the HET wells are labelled green and are in a cluster in top right corner, i.e. high fluorescence in both channels","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d1p7p","text":"the WT wells are labelled orange and are in a bottom right cluster, i.e. high fluorescence in only one channel","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aon8s","text":"the HOM wells are labelled blue and are in a top left cluster, i.e. high fluorescence in only one channel","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2kqu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"de6dm","text":"However, the results are rarely so perfect in my experience.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8e0pu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fpftu","text":"First, confirm that you are reading correctly which cluster is HOM vs WT based on the positions of your known WT wells. If you have other samples of known genotypes, also check their calls now. The HET cluster should always be in the middle so there is little risk of misidentification.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"psg6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ddpof","text":"To polish the results, a process which seems to work well:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9biea","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8gqrk","text":"Exclude any samples which have abormally high values (right click on scatterplot \u003e Exclude from analysis). It may seem like your run failed completely until you exclude those samples. Indeed, they force the plot to be extremely \"zoomed-out\", preventing to see the clusters.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82k43","text":"Is there any samples (not NTC) which are coloured in black? Exclude them. Those are labelled as NTC wells because they had low fluorescence.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"curre","text":"Exclude any NTC wells which are inside or close to another cluster.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fgdi5","text":"Exclude any wells which are in-between clusters. You essentially want to create a empty spaces between clusters.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"120ra","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8kf42","text":"A final plot looking like this is good:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"busa6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3rnq4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f7hqn","text":"If you expect a specific ratio of genotypes (e.g. 25% WT / 25% HOM / 50% HET for a heterozygous in-cross), count your results as additional check.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dfh0e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"err8l","text":"I think the software calls the genotype of each well based on a clustering algorithm.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fqh9q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"2695787F345411EEAFD10A58A9FEAC02","height":362,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":null,\"entityMap\":null}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"Screenshot 2022-12-21 at 15.01.42.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktbebc4jf.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktbcbc4jf.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/ktbdbc4jf.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ktbbbc4jf.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"13n0p","text":"You can export a PDF report with:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5glqj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7abg1","text":"Tools","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8jitm","text":"\u003e Report","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cil8c","text":"\u003e untick everything except sections Header and Allele discrimination","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2sheg","text":"\u003e Update report","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qa8n","text":"\u003e Save in your folder","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6mu38","text":"\u003e Email PDF report to yourself","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ckmq","text":"\u003e Close everything","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"95cs1","text":"    \u003e No to save template","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jjp8","text":"    \u003e Save results in your folder","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bj39m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"36ua2","text":"You can also export results in a CSV format.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3lr7j","text":"Dilute your genomic DNA.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2umkn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c4emh","text":"Your genomic DNA is likely too concentrated. This has been my recurrent experience with 8-dpf larvae lysed with HotSHOT using 50 µL BASE + 50 µL NEUTRALISATION. Even if the larvae/finclips you used were smaller, the PCR will still have ample template after dilution, and it is likely that you will get more wells with clear results.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"blgjd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"vaeh","text":"You can safely add 50–80 µL nuclease-free H2O on top of your ~ 100 µL of genomic DNA. Spin down the plate.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7726i","text":"Did not work?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8j9dj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fitbb","text":"It may be that your genomic DNA is still too concentrated. Diluting the genomic DNA has often been the solution for me. To avoid overflowing the genomic DNA plate, you can also pipet only   nuclease-free H2O +   genomic DNA in every well, instead of 2 µL genomic DNA, which will dilute by a further 2×.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":188,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":210,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a9c01","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1vhmf","text":"If that does not help, you can also try the Reverse set of primers.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"koel","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"28oo7","text":"Other troubleshooting advice? Add them here or comment on this section.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"1","error":false,"guid":"CA0C9400814211ED92F6CB7064821AB8","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"1","error":false,"guid":"D518F280814211ED92F6CB7064821AB8","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5q45k","text":"Are you using a QuantStudio 6 Pro machine? Instructions for reading the plate:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ff9b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ob1b","text":"Set up plate: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6bdsd","text":"\u003e Analysis (left panel) \u003e Genotyping","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ep51t","text":"\u003e QuandStudio 6 Pro","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"be9pk","text":"\u003e 96-well 0.1 mL","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"do4s9","text":"\u003e Run mode Standard","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dvjj3","text":"\u003e click to create Genotyping protocol","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1bgqe","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dkt1u","text":"\u003e Reaction Volume = 5 uL","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1pjpr","text":"Delete all steps using the Minus sign, except Post Read. Set to 30C / 1 min","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"94d1c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aua16","text":"\u003e Plate Setup","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a3q3v","text":"\u003e Select unknown wells. Click + on right to create new Sample. Then tick, so should all be Sample 1.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1dig0","text":"\u003e Same with SNP Assays. So should all be Sample 1 \u0026 SNP Assay 1.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"emlhm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3kr4t","text":"In SNP Assay, check the following:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"atvhu","text":"\u003e Allele 1 Reporter is VIC","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f46g2","text":"\u003e Allele 1 Quencher is NFQ-MGB","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ta4r","text":"\u003e Allele 2 Reporter is FAM","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"25s6i","text":"\u003e Allele 2 Quencher is NFQ-MGB","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bfc5m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75vf5","text":"\u003e Select your negative controls, click +, change Type to Negative Control. Tick to apply. Apply same SNP assay.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"g2lv","text":"So, NTC wells should be Sample 2 (marked N) \u0026 SNP Assay 1.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1a85u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"24vhq","text":"Make sure Passive Reference at the top is ROX.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eacvl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8c78s","text":"Run Summary, scroll down, click machine then Send to Run Queue.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c7ue5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2n5ne","text":"Browse to folder where you want to store results.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d71b2","text":"Change name.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5830h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2vish","text":"On machine, open with button top right. Load plate. Close.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bo9tn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4f6rj","text":"Load plate file, find your protocol in Run Queue (usually last for some reason).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4e69r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c1tgh","text":"Start run.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"r6bv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aaf10","text":"If file is not in expected folder, can Transfer file.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eeeau","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6c5uk","text":"Also do Actions \u003e Export to CSV.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

title: KASP genotyping
